results.title: The Gang
results.creator_credit: Sandra Richardson, Ian Munro, Tom Manefield and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “I myself”.
Honadie, Julie and Joanne are members of a gang. They believe that their peers are submissive to them because of the violence the gang has used and has threatened to use. Emphasis is on the co-operative efforts of the school, the parents and the girls themselves to effect changes in their behaviour.

results.title: The Games: the millennium bug
results.creator_credit: Bruce Permezel, Denise Eriksen, ABC-TV (Australia) and Beyond Productions
results.brief_description: The first four episodes from the ABC comedy documentary series, The Games. Episode 1: John and Gina meet the Sydney spindoctors while Bryan finds the unbelievable - a willing sponsor with millions to spend. Episode 2: John confronts the threat of the Millenium Bug, and finds a worldwide audience for The Games on the Net. Episode 3: Our team goes bush to a conference centre to workshop the problems they face at The Games. Episode 4: The consultants are out to get Bryan but our team proves that home-grown expertise can beat corporate slickness any day. Written by John Clarke and Ross Stevenson.

results.title: The Games: sharing the blame
results.creator_credit: Bruce Permezel, Finishing Touches Productions and Australian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description: This video contains four episodes from series two of the outstanding ABC series “The Games”, a satirical (but often painfully close to the truth) mock documentary of SOCOG and their preparations for the Sydney 2000 Olympic Games. The episodes included cover the following issues: an in-depth look at the lives of some of the main players behind the scenes of the Committee; what happens when everything is running according to schedule; the life story of one (or perhaps two) of the many thousands of international guests who will come to see the Games; the use of inquiries to ensure that the accidental misuse of process by Committee members is quickly exposed and rectified.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Bruce Permezel, Finishing Touches Productions and Australian Broadcasting Corporation

results.title: The Games: Olympic Variations
results.material_description: Single channel moving image, colour and audio
results.brief_description: Auder’s alternative vision of the 1984 Olympic Games in Los Angeles is composed entirely of re-scanned and re-edited footage shot directly from a television set. The athletes’ exertions, fragmented and abstracted by Auder into an incessant flow of crotch shots and body parts, take on a highly sexual, often sadomasochistic edge. Auder exploits the subliminal, raising the violent and sexual subtext of TV sports coverage to the surface. His seamlessly re-edited images and discordant sound pull the viewer into an enigmatic narrative of physicality that is intensely subjective, almost obsessive, in its focus. The underlying principle behind appropriation and ‘scratch’ video of this kind is an inclination to subvert, artistically, the political ideology reflected in the industrial source of the material and TV entertainment (Bob Riley).

results.title: The Games
results.brief_description: The Games was an Australian mockumentary television series about the 2000 Summer Olympics in Sydney. The series was originally broadcast on the ABC and had two seasons of 13 episodes each, the first in 1998 and the second in 2000.

constellations_other.name: No guts, no glory
constellations_other.description: TV arrived just in time for the 1956 Melbourne Olympics. The Olympics crystallise ideas of nationalism, athletic heroism, and controversy, all of which have been explored through countless features, documentaries and TV shows.

results.description:
The Games was an Australian mockumentary television series about the 2000 Summer Olympics in Sydney. The series was originally broadcast on the ABC and had two seasons of 13 episodes each, the first in 1998 and the second in 2000.

‘The Games’ starred satirists John Clarke and Bryan Dawe along with Australian comedian Gina Riley and actor Nicholas Bell. It was written by John Clarke and Ross Stevenson. The series centred on the Sydney Organising Committee for the Olympic Games and satirised corruption and cronyism in the Olympic movement, bureaucratic ineptness in the New South Wales public service, and unethical behaviour within politics and the media. An unusual feature of the show was that the characters shared the same name as the actors who played them, to enhance the illusion of a documentary on the Sydney Games.
description_for_label:
The Games was an Australian mockumentary television series about the 2000 Summer Olympics in Sydney. The series was originally broadcast on the ABC and had two seasons of 13 episodes each, the first in 1998 and the second in 2000.

‘The Games’ starred satirists John Clarke and Bryan Dawe along with Australian comedian Gina Riley and actor Nicholas Bell. It was written by John Clarke and Ross Stevenson. The series centred on the Sydney Organising Committee for the Olympic Games and satirised corruption and cronyism in the Olympic movement, bureaucratic ineptness in the New South Wales public service, and unethical behaviour within politics and the media. An unusual feature of the show was that the characters shared the same name as the actors who played them, to enhance the illusion of a documentary on the Sydney Games.

results.title: The Games
results.creator_credit: Bruce Permezel, Ross Stevenson, John Clarke, ABC-TV (Australia) and Beyond Productions
results.brief_description: A mock documentary about how not to prepare for the Sydney Olympics, or any Olympics for that matter. This tape includes four episodes from the popular television satire. Incidents arising from the episodes include; accuracy, in particular the construction of the 100 metre track; the importance of flying with approved airlines and what happens when two international figures arrive on a non official airline; John appears on television defending Australia’s position on the environment while Bryan and Gina hear a proposal from rural Australia regarding the opening ceremony; there are moves to bring in an infallible drug test to the Olympics, but will it bring more harm than good? Cast includes John Clarke, Gina Riley and Bryan Dawe.

results.title: The Game is up!
results.creator_credit: John Tutty, Meg Labrum and National Film and Sound Archive of Australia
results.brief_description: The National Film and Sound Archive has drawn on its unique film collection in a selection of vintage newsreels, home movies, advertisements and feature film footage looking at women’s contribution to Australia’s sporting culture. The video is accompanied by an excellent teacher resource guide. Presented in chronological order some of the highlights include Annette Kellerman’s underwater ballet in 1914, Vera James in the classic film of 1921, ‘A Girl of the bush’, The Australian Women’s Cricket team of 1937 and of course the golden girls of the Melbourne Olympics of 1956.

results.title: The Game
results.creator_credit: Michael Jenkins, ABC-TV (Australia) and Michael Carson
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Scales of Justice Series”.
The Game is a story of jealousy and conflict, personal and professional. Detective Sergeant Draffin and Miles are both from the same mould. Both are ruthlessly ambitious, both boast a reputation of being first class operators, and both are very confident of their ability. However, neither is used to sharing the limelight, and when Draffin is transferred to the Drug Squad, Miles’ home territory, the scene is set for a major confrontation. Rated: M

results.title: The Game
results.creator_credit: Les Clark, Ken Peterson and Walt Disney Educational Materials
results.brief_description: An animated film made for children, which poses the questions - how come some kids never play by the rules? Why do they always wan special treatment? Should the rules be changed? Various alternatives are offered for each problem but the real answers will be those which arise from group discussions.

results.title: The Game
results.creator_credit: Laurence Gunther, Aden Porter, Joshua Ash-Miller and Schonn-Pierre Hirst
results.brief_description:
The theme of belonging is explored by looking at rejection based on stereotypes in the schoolyard, and the effect that had on the victim. Also shown in this animated short is the impact an accepting group has on that person.

Under the category ‘Bullying. No Way! - Secondary”, Year 10, St John’s Grammar School, South Australia, were the Screen It 2012 winners.
